entries.content: Proper gain staging in REAPER: Aim for -18dBFS to -12dBFS on individual tracks for optimal headroom. Use the track trim/gain before the fader for initial level setting. Keep the master fader at 0dB and adjust individual tracks instead. Watch for red meters indicating clipping.
tips: Set input gain so peaks hit around -12dB
Use VU meters for average levels

entries.content: EQ tips for mixing: Cut before boost - remove unwanted frequencies before adding. High-pass filter vocals around 80-100Hz to remove rumble. Cut muddy frequencies around 200-400Hz. Boost presence in vocals around 3-5kHz. Use narrow Q for cutting, wide Q for boosting.
tips: High-pass everything except bass and kick

entries.content: Compression settings guide: For vocals use 3:1 to 4:1 ratio, medium attack (10-30ms), medium release. For drums use faster attack, 4:1 to 8:1 ratio. For bass use slower attack to preserve transients. Aim for 3-6dB of gain reduction on most sources.
tips: Use makeup gain to match levels

entries.content: Reverb tips: Use sends instead of inserts for reverb. Pre-delay of 20-40ms helps clarity. Short reverb (0.5-1s) for intimate, long reverb (2-4s) for epic. Roll off low frequencies on reverb returns. Delay times: 1/4 note, 1/8 note, or sync to tempo.
tips: Send to reverb bus, don't insert on tracks
Use pre-delay to separate dry signal

entries.content: Panning strategies: Keep bass, kick, snare, and lead vocals centered. Pan guitars left and right (hard pan or 50-70%). Double-tracked parts should be panned opposite. Use LCR (Left-Center-Right) panning for clarity. Pan background vocals wide.

Setting up recording in REAPER: Go to track, click input dropdown to select audio input. Enable record arm (R button). Enable input monitoring to hear yourself. Set buffer size lower (128-256) for less latency during recording. Use direct monitoring from interface if latency is an issue.

Punch-in recording: Set time selection over the section to re-record. Enable 'Auto-punch' in transport. Press record - it will only record within the selection. Use pre-roll to hear context before punch point. Alt+click on timeline for quick time selection.

Loop recording for multiple takes: Set loop points with time selection. Enable loop in transport. Record multiple passes - REAPER creates take lanes. Use Ctrl+click to audition different takes. Right-click take lane to comp best parts.

REAPER recording modes: Normal mode - record to new items. Overdub mode - layer on top of existing. Replace mode - replace existing audio. Time selection auto-punch - only record in selection. Use Options menu to change recording behavior.

Essential editing operations: S = split item at cursor. Delete = remove selected item. Ctrl+C/V = copy/paste. G = glue items. Ctrl+Z = undo (unlimited). Hold Shift while dragging for snapping. Double-click item to open in editor.

Ripple editing modes: Off - items don't move when you delete. Per-track - only items on same track shift. All tracks - all items after edit point shift. Toggle with Alt+Shift+R or button in toolbar. Essential for podcast/dialog editing.

Working with time selection: Click+drag on timeline to select time. Ctrl+Shift+click for precise selection. Tab to move between transients. Shift+Tab for previous transient. Use time selection for rendering, exporting, or operations.

Comping multiple takes: Record in loop mode to create take lanes. Click on take lane header to expand. Click sections to select best parts from each take. Right-click for 'Crop to active take'. Use Ctrl+L to show lanes.

Creating fades: Drag from top corners of item for fade in/out. Select items and press X for auto-crossfade. Double-click fade to edit curve. S-curve for smooth, Linear for quick. Set default fade length in preferences.

Creating sends: Click track routing button (Route). Add new send to destination track. Adjust send level with fader. Pre-fader send = level independent of track fader. Post-fader = follows track fader. Create bus tracks for group processing.
tips: Use sends for reverb and delay
Create drum bus for parallel compression

entries.content: Setting up sidechain: Add compressor to track (e.g., bass). In compressor, click sidechain input. Route from trigger track (e.g., kick) to compressor sidechain. Adjust compressor threshold and ratio. Classic use: duck bass when kick hits.
tips: Sidechain bass to kick for punch
Sidechain pads to vocals for clarity
Use sidechain on reverb for cleaner mix

entries.content: Using folder tracks: Right-click track > Insert folder. Drag tracks into folder. Folder track acts as submix bus. Apply processing to folder to affect all children. Collapse/expand with folder icon. Great for drum groups, vocal stacks.

Routing to hardware: Master track routes to hardware outputs by default. For multiple outputs, use track routing. Create headphone mix on separate output. Use hardware output for external effects sends. Check I/O button in mixer.
tips: Create separate cue mixes for musicians
